image.altText: Albanese gestures to his colleagues while they all wear high vis vests and

items.synopsis: The $10 billion Housing Australia Future Fund has passed parliament, paving the way for new social and affordable homes to be built.

title.children: The government's $10bn housing bill has passed parliament, paving way for 30,000 new homes

image.altText: A close up of Jacinta Nampijinpa Price.

items.synopsis: Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price is set to front the National Press Club as the Voice to Parliament referendum looms.

title.children: No campaign leader Jacinta Nampijinpa Price to front National Press Club

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Senator Price tells the Press Club the "third lie" on the Voice is that "it is simply just an advisory body". "Nowhere in the question that will be put to Australians or in the proposed chapter on which we are voting do the words 'advice' advise or advisory appear," she says. "If the Prime Minister truly intented for this body to be a simple advisory body, as he, his government and the advocates of the Voice repeatedly tell us, then it would have been stipulated in the proposed chapter." We'll be following up points like this later today with our Parliament House team.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Senator Price claims 'third lie'

children.content: Senator Price tells the Press Club the "third lie" on the Voice is that "it is simply just an advisory body".
"Nowhere in the question that will be put to Australians or in the proposed chapter on which we are voting do the words 'advice' advise or advisory appear," she says.

"If the Prime Minister truly intented for this body to be a simple advisory body, as he, his government and the advocates of the Voice repeatedly tell us, then it would have been stipulated in the proposed chapter."
We'll be following up points like this later today with our Parliament House team.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Senator Price says despite "racial stereotyping", Aboriginal Australians are not a single group and have "often disagreed on many political positions". "Indigenous Australians have a long history of engaging and contribute to our communities, our country and our democratic process," she says. "And we have done it in different areas, in different fields, with different approaches and different skills. "Despite racial stereotyping, that suggests Aboriginal Australians are one homogenous group. We are not. "We have participated in public debate throughout our nation's history and we have often disagreed on many political positions. "The incredible contributions, many Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians made to our nation, contributing to it, not trying to tear it apart. "It's one of the greatest strengths and sources of pride for our country."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Long history' of Indigenous contribution

children.content: Senator Price says despite "racial stereotyping", Aboriginal Australians are not a single group and have "often disagreed on many political positions".
"Indigenous Australians have a long history of engaging and contribute to our communities, our country and our democratic process," she says.
"And we have done it in different areas, in different fields, with different approaches and different skills.
"Despite racial stereotyping, that suggests Aboriginal Australians are one homogenous group. We are not.
"We have participated in public debate throughout our nation's history and we have often disagreed on many political positions.
"The incredible contributions, many Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians made to our nation, contributing to it, not trying to tear it apart.
"It's one of the greatest strengths and sources of pride for our country."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Senator Price says the voice should be "rejected resolutely". "I am one of 11 Indigenous voices currently in parliament and I will not accept the lie, the rationalisation of many Indigenous voices of the yes campaign who suggest our democratically elected voices are redundant because we belong to political parties. "The patronising suggestion that we cannot focus our efforts on improving the lives of marginalised Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders because we are looking after constituents should be rejected resolutely. "It is a suggestion that's offensive, not only to me, but my coalition colleague, Kerryanne Liddle. But to all that are Indigenous heritage in Federal Parliament."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Voice 'offensive' to Indigenous politicians, says Price

children.content: Senator Price says the voice should be "rejected resolutely" .

"I am one of 11 Indigenous voices currently in parliament and I will not accept the lie, the rationalisation of many Indigenous voices of the yes campaign who suggest our democratically elected voices are redundant because we belong to political parties.

"The patronising suggestion that we cannot focus our efforts on improving the lives of marginalised Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders because we are looking after constituents should be rejected resolutely.
"It is a suggestion that's offensive, not only to me, but my coalition colleague, Kerryanne Liddle. But to all that are Indigenous heritage in Federal Parliament."

title.children: Unemployment rate steady at 3.7pc, Myer profits up 23pc, local shares open slightly higher

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That's according to Diana Mousina, AMP's deputy chief economist. She says as the full effects of the RBA's interest rate rises flow through the economy, coupled with increased migration, the jobless rate will tick up in the coming months. "We think the unemployment rate in a year's time will be over 4.5%, if we get a significant downturn then it could be at 5%, if not even a little bit higher, but our base case is for 4.5% from here," she said. "If you put that into context, that is still quite a favourable outcome for Australia, because before the pandemic, it was difficult for the unemployment rate to get under 5.5%, so the fact that we do have this unemployment rate that's likely to still remain at very low levels compared to history, I think should still be considered a good outcome. "But the unemployment rate will rise, which is a natural impact of rising interest rates, so unfortunately, that means that more people will be out of work. "That will be a hit to household incomes, which is why we are generally semi-concerned about the outlook for the economy, we think economic growth is going to slow in the next 12 months ."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Unemployment rate could rise above 4.5 per cent in 12 months' time

Diana Mousina, AMP's deputy chief economist

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Deputy chief economist at AMP, Diana Mousina, says today's unemployment data shows the Australian labour market remains resilient. She spoke to finance presenter Sue Lannin a short time ago, and says there there are signs the market is weakening. "I would say the labour market does still look quite strong across the board, however we have seen some tick-up in the unemployment rate, the unemployment rate bottomed at at 3.4%, now it's at 3.7%," she said. "The August figures are showing that underutilisation in the labour market, which is ultimately people who want to work more hours has ticked up as well a little bit. "I think that there are definitely some signs of some weakening that's going to come in the workforce, not to mention all the leading indicators of jobs growth, things like labour hiring intentions and job vacancies, they've all come down quite significantly from levels last year. "So the labour market is still going to show signs of slowing but it's taking a lot longer than most economists have been anticipating and what the RBA has been expecting as well ."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Labour market looks 'quite strong across the board', economist says

children.content: Deputy chief economist at AMP,
Diana Mousina
, says today's unemployment data shows the Australian labour market remains resilient.
She spoke to finance presenter Sue Lannin a short time ago, and says there there are signs the market is weakening.

"I would say the labour market does still look quite strong across the board, however we have seen some tick-up in the unemployment rate, the unemployment rate bottomed at at 3.4%, now it's at 3.7%," she said.
"The August figures are showing that
underutilisation in the labour market,
which is ultimately
people who want to work more hours has ticked up
as well a little bit.
"I think that there are
definitely some signs of some weakening that's going to come in the workforce
, not to mention all the leading indicators of jobs growth, things like
labour hiring intentions
and
job vacancies
, they've
all come down quite significantly
from levels last year.
"So the
labour market is still going to show signs of slowing
but
it's taking a lot longer
than most economists have been anticipating and
what the RBA has been expecting as well

props.alt: A woman sitting in an office chair at home.

children.content: AMP deputy chief economist Diana Mousina.
(ABC News)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Aussie dollar is up +0.2% to $US64.34 following news the unemployment rate remained steady in August at 3.7%. The All Ordinaries and ASX 200 are also up about +0.3 % (at 12.00pm AEST). BDO Economics Partner Anders Magnusson says a low unemployment rate usually indicates that things are good for households. "However, this is currently accompanied by high multiple job holdings and increasing hours worked per employee, which suggests otherwise. With costs rising more quickly than wages, Australians are working more jobs and longer hours to make ends meet." It all means there is unlikely to be further interest rate hikes from the Reserve Bank next month. Mr Magnusson says he expects inflation to continue decreasing. "Simultaneously low unemployment should be viewed by the RBA as a good thing rather than an inflation risk. Especially as wages have continued to grow by less than inflation over the last year."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Aussie dollar up after jobs data

children.content: The Aussie dollar is up +0.2% to $US64.34 following news the unemployment rate remained steady in August at 3.7%.
The All Ordinaries and ASX 200 are also up about +0.3 % (at 12.00pm AEST).
BDO Economics Partner Anders Magnusson says a low unemployment rate usually indicates that things are good for households.
"However, this is currently accompanied by high multiple job holdings and increasing hours worked per employee, which suggests otherwise.
With costs rising more quickly than wages, Australians are working more jobs and longer hours to make ends meet."
It all means there is
unlikely to be further interest rate hikes from the Reserve Bank next month
Mr Magnusson says he expects
inflation to continue decreasing.
"Simultaneously low unemployment should be viewed by the RBA as a good thing rather than an inflation risk.
Especially as wages have continued to grow by less than inflation over the last year."
